etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French pluralite, from late Latin pluralitas, from Latin pluralis ‘relating to more than one’ (see plural)

notes.text: On the difference between plurality and majority, see majority

definitions: the fact or state of being plural

examples.text: some languages add an extra syllable to mark plurality

shortDefinitions: fact or state of being plural

definitions: a large number of people or things
shortDefinitions: large number of people or things

definitions: the number of votes cast for a candidate who receives more than any other but does not receive an absolute majority

examples.text: his winning plurality came from creating a reform coalition

shortDefinitions: number of votes for candidate receiving more than others but not absolute majority

definitions: the number by which plurality exceeds the number of votes cast for the candidate who placed second.
shortDefinitions: number by which plurality exceeds votes for candidate placed second

examples.text: he obtained dispensations to hold several benefices in plurality
